data.text: E-Bike Batteries on a Plane?
Good day folks, has anyone flown with a ebike batttery?? Or any advice to do so. TIAüö≤
As far as I'm aware you can't as its lithium but best to check with the airline of your choice.
data.author: Anthony Taylor

data.text: Buy one and get it delivered to destination. Sell it afterwards to a local. Posting your own is difficult as postal services will not take it either without a lot of paperwork.
data.author: Iain Urquhart

data.text: Unfortunately you cannot fly with an ebike battery. They are banned from all passenger flights by IATA which sets the rules for airlines on a range of things.
data.author: Steve Molloy

data.text: more antiquated and reactionary senseless rules... Like one guy a had a poorly crafted device in his shoe, and now everyone has to be screened... üôÑ
data.author: Jimmy Koyote

data.text: Lithium batteries have caused fires and fatal crashes, It's not a knee-jerk reaction
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text:
More than 70 instances of fires. https://www.consumerreports.org/faa/battery-fire-in-delta-cargo-hold/
Fire on Delta Airlines Flight Highlights Danger from Lithium-Ion Batteries
consumerreports.org
data.author: Stephen Cieply

data.text: I understand as much.. But wondering what would happen if it magically found itself on the plane...

data.text: I‚Äôm sure everything as big as a bicycle gets X-rayed. And then removed most likely.

data.text: in antiquated devices. Just about everything you're going to get now is puncture and shock proof- which along with overheating causes battery fires.
data.author: Jimmy Koyote

data.text: Err No Jimmy Koyote that‚Äôs pretty dumb statements. Please post your whereabouts at all times I don‚Äôt ever want to be on the same plane as you, assuming you reach planet Earth sometime........

data.text: Look into grin technologies, they have battery packs designed for that/loop hole in the rules
data.author: William Rourke

data.text: look at Bike Friday website. Their add on systems split each cell into its own battery and therefore each are under the ah limit. So instead of carrying 1 battery that exceeds the ah limit, you are carrying 12 little ones that are under the limit.
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: Phone the airline each one is different.I‚Äôve heard people say they had to send it independently by post
data.author: Mark Hepworth

data.text: I‚Äôve flown with someone who has one several times. Just check ‚Äúno‚Äù when they ask. They scan the box but can‚Äôt tell it‚Äôs a battery. Haven‚Äôt ever opened it.

data.author: Travis Reece

data.text: I spoken to a few cargo companies and they regularly ship battries of this size and bigger. It all about the packaging to defuse any risk.
data.author: Christiaan Hellinger

data.text: Over 99 watt hours is not allowed as checkin or carryon in an airline. Some brands like specialized you can bring your bike without a battery then rent a battery at a specialized Bikeshop. You would have to inquire ahead if the have that service.
data.author: Raymund Casambre

data.text: Call your specific airline(s) and ask. They will read you the rules right off of their computer reservation screen as posted by the FAA/IATA. much better advice then taking the advise of unknowns in a group who may not work for an airline.
data.author: Travis Reece

data.text: I hear its better as a carry on , if your battery catches fire the cabin attendants can get to it to put out the fire rather than having the whole plane go down, burning in the luggage hold..
data.author: Robert Clark
